reviews.review_msg: I recommend taking this class if you're an anthro major. I think that if you have an understanding of anthro concepts you'll do fine. This class is an easy pass if you do the readings, speak up in class when you have a chance, and show Noel you're making an effort. interesting content, lectures are dry, but easy A if you know what you're doing.

The class was a seminar but was taught like a lecture. Participation was worth 25% of the grade, so having a lecture-style seminar made it difficult to participate. The rest of the final grade was based on 2 exams and 1 final 800-word paper. Get ready to read and understand the texts, as well as memorize who wrote what.

I have taken 2 class with Noel, and he is great! His teaching style is old school - no online submissions/canvas or power point presentations. lectures can feel long sometimes, but always informative. If you are truly passionate about anthropology you will appreciate and enjoy his classes although I may not recommend for ppl who aren't.

Noel's exams are basic. Participation marks are a big part of your grade. He asks cryptic open-ended questions with specific answers that are hard to guess, but you get used to it. The readings and course content make up for somewhat lackluster lectures. You could do a lot worse than a prof that's a little boring. The workload is not heavy.

If you do not like seminar style courses, you will not do well. Be sure to participate in discussions... it counts towards your grade big time. I do wish there was more group work in this class.. I feel it would have added more to the discussions. Good teacher overall, he enjoys what he teaches.

Noel is the most boring professor I have ever had. The course material was interesting, but his lectures were useless. He asked us to hand in questions at the beginning of each class and he spent 4 hours reading them out loud along with possible answers. No slides. No group discussion. And participation is worth 20% with no chance to even talk.
VERY boring, VERY dry, read both books RELIGIOUSLY but did not receive a good grade, it even dragged my GPA. Would not recommend this course with him.

Dyck is very nice in person but this course is something like Philosophy you either get it or you don't. If you are a fast and excellent writer then you'll do fine. Tests are all written 3 short ans worth 10% each then 2 longer answers worth 30% each. The final paper was %30 on what you learned in the course max 800 words but he varies it each sem.

Extremely difficult, hardest 100 level course ever. His lecture materials are not clear, and you don't even have to attend. The term paper is super challenging because you're require to write something special. If you write something similar to others, both of you would have lower mark!! What is this for?

Dyck is a terrible professor, but a decent guy. It was very boring, his slides were not helpful or useful, I think he expected students to take notes from what he says. Very passionate and knowledgable about his work, but I didn't learn anything in this class. If you were to ask me what anthropology was, I would not have an answer..

This course, BEWARE do not take with Noel because he can kill your spirit. He stopped giving slide points and when he is "lecturing" half the class can't hear him. He may love what he teaches but he makes students hate it. My worst course this semester at this point only the finals can save me. I don't understand one thing and the TAs don't either.

He lectures directly from textbook then adds one or two of his own examples. The TA doesn't know what he wants her to do either. Know the concepts and the names of everyone in the book. He starts off the course with tacky prezi presentations, then the second half of the course he has no visual aid. READ THE TEXT BOOK. Hes a nice guy though.
I thought this class would be interesting and easy but it isn't. Noel is a really hard marker, and he's not a good teacher.

Relied heavily on the textbook including the one he wrote, TA seemed just as confused in what was being taught. Wanted to get a major in anthropology before I took this class. Now after I hate the subject. worst class.

A good guy who knows his field and has a comprehensive understanding of the material he's teaching. Unfortunately, this doesn't necessarily carry over into the learning experience of the class. Is always looking for a super-specific answer/assignment, and his explanations leave me feeling lost and insufficiently respected, honestly.

I thought Dr. Dyck was a great prof and a nice guy, but I agree that he is very vague as to what he is looking for, and by sheer luck I managed to guess right and do well. It's a good course and he offers highly varied content, lots of interesting films. Participation was worth 30%.

Um, confusing and kind of intimidating. He has these answers that he's looking for but he doesn't really know how to frame his questions properly. Assignments aren't explained too clearly...just confused. Weird class.

Wow, where to begin. Just boring. Keep up with the readings or you're screwed. Doesn't allow food or laptops in class - probably worried students will be more interested in surfing the net than listening to him. Good guess.
Dull. His "teaching" will put you to sleep. But I barely read the book and still got a B+. Not that hard of a marker.

Noel took incredibly interesting material with a lot of potential, and turned it into a painfully dull class. He is long-winded and boring, the questions he puts to the class to stimulate discussion often left people confused and uncertain. Also, his requirements for papers were irritatingly unclear, and his explanations were no help.

Taught theory basically out of the (exceedingly dull) textbook. In no way attempted to make lectures dynamic. Assignments suffered in quality; while I enjoyed one of the ethnographies, the other was an absolute fight to get through. This course with this prof was not worth my time.

Very boring teaching format. Chose old studies,books,etc. but didn't show their relevance. Made interesting topics boring and unimportant.  Didn't even mention current events relevant to topics discussed. Would NOT recommend taking a class with him. Easy class but not worth the boredom. If you can, take a class with the amazing Ann Travers instead.
Really enjoyed taking this class. The readings were interesting, the TAs were very helpful, and the prof has a great teaching style.

Good interesting proff, keeping up with readings is crucial to keep up with his lectures. However, very confusing, I agree with the latter comment, went to his office hours several times for help on essays and only left me more confused. I would not take another class with him, he is to unclear about what he wants in his class.

i have mixed feelings about noel.he is a great person no doubt,but he was very intimidating during class cause he always wants pin-point answers. he has a specific answer that he's looking for and it's always a guessing game in class.very helpful, BUT also very confusing. after 1hr in his office, i came out more confused then i was when i went in.
Simply the best professor in the department!
Great teacher, very respectful of students.Highly recommended. Lots of reading--it is interesting.
The most approachable prof ever. Clearly loves teaching; encouraging of critical, independent thought.
Lots of reading in this class. Doesn't talk down to students and has a lot of patience. I'd love to take another class with him.
This guy knows his stuff. He wrote one of the textbooks for the class. Got to keep up with the readings though. He makes stuff interesting and encourages seminar participation.
